title: 111_s1071
content: The "Protecting America's Communities Act" prohibits the admission or parole of aliens who were detained at Guantanamo Bay Naval Base as of January 1, 2009, under the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 3. DETENTION AUTHORITY. Section 241(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security" and includes a provision for Guantanamo Bay detainees to be detained for an additional 6 months if unable to be removed. The Secretary may renew a certification without limitation after providing the alien with an opportunity to request reconsideration and submit supporting evidence. The Secretary may not delegate the authority to make or renew a certification to an official below the level of the Assistant Secretary for Immigration and Customs Enforcement. No immigration judge or official of United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement may release from detention on bond or parole any alien described in the previous paragraph. SEC. 4 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to make Guantanamo Bay detainees ineligible for asylum. SEC. 5 mandates the detention of aliens from Guantanamo Bay Naval Base. SEC. 5 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to require the detention of aliens from Guantanamo Bay Naval Base as of January 1, 2009. Congress reaffirms the President's authority to detain enemy combatants in the armed conflict with al Qaeda, the Taliban, and associated forces until the conflict ends, regardless of where they are captured. This authority does not limit the President's constitutional power to detain enemy combatants in this or any other armed conflict.
